climbs.name: Here Comes Sickness aka Germ Free Adolescent Right Sit

content.description:
The crux is from the start to getting established in the jug system of

GFA

stand.  Start hands matched in a rail with two crimps on either side do a jump move to a decent, left hand sloper.  Right foot up and cross to a good crimp, jump to the jug system and top out as for

GFA

.  The name "Here Comes Sickness" comes from the Benningfield guide, which is prone to all sorts of errors.  Any corrections are welcome.
content.protection: A pad for the start and several for the finish and a spotter to keep you off the tree.

content.description:
Some hardish moves at the start leads into the jug system where

GFA

stand begins. Finish as for

GFA

, the full line!  Start sitting matched down and left of the jug system. Stick the knob with the left hand, right hand to a decent sloper and then cross to a good pinch. Pew.... Donsies.
content.protection: A few pads at the start and a few at the end. Bring a good spotter to keep you off the tree.
content.location:
This is the left start to

GFA

proper. It is across the stream from the Milton Boulder.

climbs.name: Germ Free Adolescence
climbs.fa: pretty sure it was John Sherman

content.description: The crux is coming over the lip, after hitting the big right hand crimp...the holds are all there, extremely solid.  Make sure you position pads strategically, because it's good size and hitting the ground from the lip hurts.  One hell of a problem.
content.protection: Pads and spotter necessary unless you are planning an onsight.
content.location: This is the obvious line out the center of the boulder, you can't miss it.
